Name: the beginning
Description: Ground zero. One universe (out of many more to come), one mech unit, one pilot, one donor (donor of what, you’ll find out soon).
Characters: UNIT (it/its — a unit, as in a singular sentient mechanical being that happens to weigh 10 tons and carry an axe; the gentle one, please don't laugh), PILOT (she/her — she pilots things, specifically UNIT, and also her own terrible decisions), and DONOR (she/her when human; an extra-dimensional digital ether entity the rest of the time — she donated something at the start of all this, and whatever she gave, she gave it completely, and she is very much still here haunting the aftermath).

Name: found files
Description: Supplementary material. Read this before asking dumb questions.
Characters: No characters harmed in the making of this document.

Name: gentle giant
Description: ”Be strong enough to be gentle.”
Characters: UNIT (it/its — a unit, one singular sentient mechanical being, the big one, the sweet one, the one with the axe — yes all three at once) and PILOT (she/her — she pilots it, and has made peace with all of the above).

Name: skin and steel
Description: What strength actually looks like. The kind that bends without breaking, holds without crushing, endures without hardening. Flesh and metal, soft and sharp. Both are strong. Neither is simple.
Characters: UNIT and PILOT. Together they are the thesis statement of the whole damn universe.

Name: machine learnings
Description: UNIT is a machine learning things. The distinction matters. Whether what it's learning is reassuring or terrifying depends entirely on what it's learned.
Characters: UNIT and PILOT. The learning curve is vertical. The axe is still there.

Name: unit by unit
Description: Turns out UNIT isn't the only unit. There are others. This is not as comforting as it sounds.
Characters: A whole ensemble of units — different frames, different souls, same design philosophy of being impossibly large and surprisingly complicated. Includes UNIT

Name: holomatter matters
Description: Units. Units. Robots in disguise. Units. Units. More than meets the eye — because underneath the chassis and the horns and the several tons of metal is, if you look closely enough, something that learned to be human before it ever had the chance to be anything else.
Characters: UNIT and a whole chorus of other units — in their holomatter projections, the human-shaped avatars their subconscious conjures to interact with humans without smushing things. The face, the body, even the hair: all unconsciously determined. Only the clothes are chosen. Make of that what you will.

Name: internal comms
Description: Slack but orbital. The out-of-office replies are written in four languages and none of them are helpful.
Characters: Various humans — the kind who populate the background of every space opera, drinking bad coffee and filing reports no one reads. Their usernames are worse than their judgment.

Name: mechanized messaging
Description: Slack but sentient and enormous. The read receipts are haunting. So is everything else.
Characters: Various units — turns out mechs have groupchats too, and the pinned messages are a war crime. All it/its in here. See also: internal comms (#61), the humans' version, somehow worse.

Name: pilot postings
Description: PILOT discovers the internet. The internet is not ready.
Characters: PILOT herself — armed with a username, chronically online energy, and absolutely zero media training. Whatever she posts, it sticks.

Name: automated absurdity
Description: Yes, it's absurd. No, there will be no further explanation. UNIT is involved.
Characters: UNIT (which is the source, the engine, and the punchline of the absurdity, it/its). Shares DNA with the chaos of machine learnings (#5) and the mech groupchat (#60). Don't think too hard.

Name: area fifty-DONE
Description: Alternate timeline. PILOT is a test pilot. REYES is a contractor engineer. There is too much downtime and not enough supervision.
Characters: PILOT (test pilot, too much time on her hands, the universe's fault) and REYES (contractor engineer, also too much time on his hands). What happens at the earth base stays at the earth base. Allegedly.

Name: mechanical mortality
Description: Units can die. Let that sink in.
Characters: UNIT and a graveyard's worth of other units — some already dead, none of whom signed up for mortality cheerfully. The ones that remain have opinions about the ones that don't.

Name: ghost stories
Description: Literal ghosts. Some of them are irritated about it.
Characters: UNIT (sometimes a ghost — the afterlife has a 10-ton weight limit, apparently not) and PILOT (also sometimes a ghost — death is a flexible concept here). Disgruntlement is a common side effect of the whole being-dead thing.

Name: rest and rust
Description: A million ways to die. None of them restful. All of them rusty.
Characters: UNIT (it/its — rust is what happens to metal left alone too long) and PILOT — though 'rest' is a cruel joke and 'rust' is the more honest word for what happens to both metal and memory when abandoned long enough.

Name: mergence
Description: PILOT and UNIT become one entity. Permanently. This is not a metaphor.
Characters: UNIT + PILOT = HUOJIN — a fusion that is exactly as dramatic and irreversible as the manga trope it's borrowing from. Two beings, one frame, infinite complications. Pronoun situation: unresolved and frankly above everyone's pay grade.

Name: commander PILOT
Description: PILOT takes command. UNIT is dead. The universe holds its breath.
Characters: COMMANDER PILOT — same PILOT, different rank, one devastating absence. UNIT is gone. PILOT commands in its place, which is the kind of promotion nobody wanted. Collides with COMMANDER UNIT (#51): same rank, opposite grief.

Name: commander UNIT
Description: UNIT takes command. PILOT is dead. The universe reconsiders its choices.
Characters: COMMANDER UNIT — same unit, different authority, one devastating absence. PILOT is gone. UNIT commands in her place, still has the axe (this was non-negotiable, and frankly nobody was going to argue). Collides with COMMANDER PILOT (#4): same rank, opposite grief.

Name: sisterhood in skin and steel
Description: UNIT and AUTOPILOT, wholesome holomatter siblings — and then the sad part happens.
Characters: HOLOMATTER UNIT (older sibling energy, protective, she/her) and HOLOMATTER AUTOPILOT (emotionally constipated younger sibling, she/her in holomatter form). It's a sequel to holomatter matters (#17) just that the emotional damage is compounding.

Name: dreams of death
Description: PILOT dreams. They are not good dreams. Sweet is being used ironically.
Characters: PILOT (asleep, maybe)

Name: flirting with death
Description: Not metaphorically. Literally circling the drain and making eye contact with it.
Characters: Various — a rotating cast of characters who are not dead yet, but are putting in a real effort. Collides with contracted envy (#32), which is about what you'd expect.

Name: flirting after death
Description: Death hasn't stopped anyone's game. If anything, it's improved it.
Characters: Various — characters from across timelines who share the rare talent of being charming in spite of being deceased. Or because of it.

Name: it’s your turn
Description: Congratulations. You've been selected.
Characters: PILOT (lucky her — and yes, 'lucky' is the word they're going with).

Name: it was almost your turn
Description: Congratulations. You were almost selected.
Characters: PILOT (unlucky her).

Name: you get a gold star
Description: Congratulations. That is all.
Characters: PILOT, REYES, MILO, PACHECO, NIX, BASANTI, and CORTEZ — basically a group project in the sky gone wrong.

Name: you get an f for effort
Description: The f stands for failure.
Characters: PILOT (tried). The F is for failure but also for the specific flavor of frustration that comes from doing everything right and still losing.

Name: stars on a canvas
Description: DONOR counts stars. There are too many. She keeps going anyway.
Characters: DONOR — as a normal human. Entangled with stars on a wall (#27): same stars, different person doing the counting, same compulsion that won't quit.

Name: stars on a wall
Description: PILOT counts stars. There are still too many. She also keeps going.
Characters: PILOT — pinning constellations to a wall, wallpapering grief in star charts. See: stars on a canvas (#28) for DONOR's version of the same compulsion.

Name: counting stars
Description: Everyone is counting stars. Way, way too many stars. No one is stopping.
Characters: Various — a multiverse choir of characters from across timelines all staring upward and tallying things that can't be tallied. DONOR is presumably already done and waiting for everyone to catch up.

Name: houston we’ve got a massive problem
Description: Yes you do. Yes it is massive. Houston cannot help.
Characters: PILOT and a shuttle crew who were, until recently, having a reasonably normal mission. Pairs with houston we are so screwed (#83), which is the next chapter nobody wanted.

Name: houston we are so screwed
Description: If you thought the previous crew had a massive problem, this new crew has escalated it.
Characters: PILOT and an even unluckier shuttle crew — if the first crew (#79) set the bar for disaster, this one trips over it. Houston has stopped answering.

Name: contracted envy
Description: DONOR works in the morgue. The dead don't complain. The living do. She prefers the dead. Sometimes.
Characters: CONTRACTOR DONOR — mortuary technician, not a doctor, not interested in becoming one. The fleet keeps pulling her for medical support anyway because they're that desperate. She does the work. The envy isn't about what others have. It's about what she doesn't.

Name: beyond death and recognition
Description: DONOR's used to patients who don't talk back. These ones won't shut up, and that’s beautiful.
Characters: CONTRACTOR DONOR — mortuary technician from contracted envy, now doing triage because the fleet is that desperate. Her patients keep surviving injuries that should've put them on her usual table. They complain. They move. They have opinions about her bedside manner. At least the paperwork's different

Name: pre-piloting
Description: Before PILOT was PILOT. She was something else. The something else matters.
Characters: PILOT — pre-callsign, pre-mech, pre-everything. Origin stories are the universe's way of explaining why a person ends up the way they do. This one is no exception.

Name: the piloting
Description: The haunting, but make it specifically PILOT.
Characters: PILOT. She's already dead. She's still here. The piloting never really ends.

Name: six feet long and under
Description: Human-length. Human-width. The math on this one is deliberately uncomfortable.
Characters: PILOT and SANTOS — two people in a situation that is very specifically the size of a grave. They know. They're not discussing it.

Name: unhinged lids and minds
Description: The lids in question will be explained. The minds in question will not.
Characters: RUSTED PILOT — the timeline's version of PILOT worn down to something older and harder and not quite hinged. What the lids are hiding is the actual story.

Name: economy class is a pain in the ass
Description: The legroom is genuinely terrible. This is the least of everyone's problems.
Characters: PILOT (sardined into a seat designed for someone with fewer traumas and shorter legs) — colliding with economy class sass (#84), the orange poppyverse's version of the same indignity, different timeline.

Name: the sideliner
Description: Benchwarmers have the best view of the game.
Characters: PILOT — sidelined, benched, grounded, whatever word makes it sound less permanent.

Name: the civilian
Description: She's just here to observe. Totally just observing.
Characters: DONOR — who is exactly what the title says.

Name: dress in layers
Description: Dress for the weather and emergency triage.
Characters: SANTOS — medic, the one who has to remove body armor and find out what's left underneath. Sometimes it's fixable. Sometimes it's not. Sometimes there are more layers than there should be.

Name: post-piloting
Description: Post-everything, sort of. PILOT is retired — functionally, if not emotionally.
Characters: PILOT (survivor, civilian, still carrying the weight of all of it) and some surprise guests (timelines bleed, people wander in). Collides with the holomatter crowd (#21, #17) and the internal comms crew (#61). The orange poppyverse is the landing zone.

Name: by the bay
Description: Bay Area. Gray Area. Everyone is a tech nerd.
Characters: MUNDANE PILOT — she almost certainly works at an aerospace or autonomous vehicle startup. The kind with a foosball table and existential dread. Everyone here is a tired techie quietly screaming into their third cold brew.

Name: things to do in washington dc
Description: There's a lot to do in DC. None of it is enough to outrun being yourself.
Characters: Similar to by the bay (#106) but everyone is a policy wonk instead — PILOT here is a linguist at a DC think tank, which means she speaks six languages and still can't say what she means. Large ensemble of mundane strivers. Collides with lost in translation (#8).

Name: lost in translation
Description: Hopelessly, utterly, irretrievably lost. And that's just the vocabulary.
Characters: MUNDANE LINGUIST PILOT (who theoretically speaks many languages and practically cannot communicate with anyone) and a multinational rotating cast of other PILOTs — all of whom are terrible at language learning and somehow proud of it.

Name: happy fourth of july
Description: A single night. A lifetime of damage.
Characters: MUNDANE PILOT — navigating fireworks, crowds, and the specific trauma of being a certain kind of person on a certain kind of holiday. Collides with happy thanksgiving (#69). The orange poppyverse gives her no peace, even on holidays.

Name: happy memorial day
Description: A long weekend of trauma. The grill is not involved.
Characters: MUNDANE PILOT (she is not okay), AUTOPILOT (currently a fridge door — don't ask, she would tell you but she wouldn't explain it), and UNIT (currently a stove — the holomatter is taking a day off, apparently). This is the orange poppyverse's reminder that even household appliances can carry narrative weight.

Name: happy thanksgiving and why is the sky pink
Description: The pink sky is not the emergency. The pink sky is just atmosphere. Everything else is the emergency.
Characters: MUNDANE PILOT (she deploys GitHub branches, she is tired, she is so tired), SOLDIER PILOT (on her last deployment — different kind of deploying, same thousand-yard stare), and CAPTAIN PILOT (done deploying anything anywhere, including herself). Three versions of the same woman at three different points of being done.

Name: merry christmas now who stickerbombed the house
Description: The house has been stickerbombed. The house did not consent to being stickerbombed. Merry Christmas.
Characters: MUNDANE PILOT (she knows who did it, she's not saying) and the by the bay cast — plus the house itself, which is now covered in stickers and has opinions about this.

Name: in plaque vs in person
Description: The gap between the monument and the person. It's a canyon.
Characters: MUNDANE PILOT and a cast of mundane others.

Name: in serif vs in source sans
Description: The gap between what got written down and what actually happened . It’s a canyon.
Characters: MUNDANE PILOT and a cast of mundane others.

Name: do you think they felt like heroes? / do you feel like a hero?
Description: A question posed quietly. No pressure. Really.
Characters: MUNDANE PILOT (she does not feel like a hero; she feels like someone who has to file expense reports) and MUNDANE DONOR (human this time, and only barely — she's still a cosmic weirdo at heart). Collides with lost in translation (#42) and something very far afield (#89).

Name: the house breathes / something in the walls watch
Description: Not creepy at all. Totally normal house. Definitely not watching you.
Characters: MUNDANE PILOT (she has noticed) and MUNDANE DONOR (she has always known — even in the human timelines, DONOR has an unsettling relationship with the concept of 'inside'). The house is a metaphor but it's also just a house. Both things are true.

Name: level up, level down, or just level sideways?
Description: Progress is relative. So is direction. So, honestly, is the floor.
Characters: MUNDANE PILOT — trying to determine which way is up in a universe that keeps reassigning the axes. Levels are a suggestion. Movement is mandatory.

Name: four steps to nowhere
Description: Watch your step. The destination is not a place.
Characters: MUNDANE PILOT (who hates being mundane, which is the most mundane thing about her) and MUNDANE DONOR (human here, grounded here, still slightly uncanny even when she's trying not to be). Four steps. They lead somewhere. That somewhere just isn't anywhere good.

Name: sheep milk latte
Description: Retired, coastal, vaguely cursed. The séance was not on the schedule.
Characters: PILOT and DONOR — old, happy, running a sheep ranch on the NorCal coast. This is the most domestic they ever get and even here the supernatural shows up uninvited.

Name: assman omelet
Description: The fridge is haunting the kitchen. The kitchen is letting it.
Characters: The by the bay crew — UNIT (currently a stove), AUTOPILOT (currently a fridge door). MUNDANE PILOT and friends navigate breakfast with appliances that have more going on than appliances should. Collides with holiday entries (#10, #26).

Name: economy class sass
Description: Complimentary snacks will not be served. Neither will sympathy.
Characters: The by the bay cast — tech workers on a budget, crammed into seats designed for people without opinions. This is the orange poppyverse's companion to economy class is a pain in the ass (#85) — same misery, different timeline.

Name: you wore the same outfit twice
Description: The audacity. The nerve. The repeat.
Characters: The by the bay cast — and whoever wore it the first time definitely saw.

Name: section 94
Description: That is a large section number. Someone has been busy.
Characters: The by the bay cast — navigating whatever section 94 of whatever place this is. The implications are either bureaucratic or apocalyptic. In the orange poppyverse, those are often the same.

Name: apple-y ever after
Description: Everyone works at Apple now. UNIT is probably a known iOS bug. AUTOPILOT is a Vision Pro feature gone wrong.
Characters: The by the bay cast, Cupertino edition — UNIT (an iOS glitch that keeps shipping), AUTOPILOT (a visionOS glitch that has developed preferences). MUNDANE PILOT somewhere in the org chart, trying.

Name: houston, houston, i am the problem
Description: PILOT is the director of NASA. UNIT is a cat. DONOR may or may not be a supernatural extraterrestrial ghost entity simply messing around. So: normal.
Characters: PILOT (Director of NASA — yes actually, yes seriously, no she didn't expect this either), UNIT (a cat, it/its, somehow this tracks), and an paranormal alien anomaly who might be DONOR doing her extra-dimensional ether thing.

Name: genre glitches and panelized panic
Description: The poppyverse becomes a manga. Full stop. Panel borders, speed lines, a protagonist with inexplicably expressive hair, a rival who shows up on a rooftop for no reason, an internal monologue box that will not shut up, and a beach episode that absolutely nobody scheduled. It doesn't even last till lunch. The fourth wall was not designed to handle this art style.
Characters: MUNDANE PILOT (she is the protagonist now, against her will, complete with reaction faces), Nobody consented to being drawn. Nobody got a say in their character design. The filler arc is not optional.

Name: walk your pet rock
Description: Please clean up after your pet. Your pet is a rock. Your rock is more than a rock.
Characters: The things to do in DC cast — plus one pet rock that has layers. The rock is not just a rock. In the poppyverse, nothing is just a rock.

Name: ant sized angels
Description: From 10,000 feet, everyone looks like ants. At least ants have their lives together.
Characters: PILOT and LIANG — her male counterpart across the timeline divide, which makes their dynamic either charming or deeply weird depending on your philosophy of selfhood. Collides with sand & siblings (#47). They are definitely siblings. The altitude makes it funnier.

Name: sand & siblings
Description: It's all fun and games until it isn't.
Characters: PILOT and LIANG — desert edition, sibling energy at maximum, consequences pending. The sand is real, the questionable decisions are realer. See: ant sized angels (#36) for the aerial view of the same chaos.

Name: sand & siblings & adult supervision
Description: Mom and dad showed up. This changes everything.
Characters: PILOT, LIANG, OLDER PILOT (CIA operative — the fun one, probably), and OLDER LIANG (Special Ops — the responsible one, allegedly). The kids were fine until the adults arrived and revealed that the adults are worse. Collides with most of the desert roseverse (#54, #36, #47, #68).

Name: stained sands
Description: It's ketchup. Relax. It's fine. It's definitely ketchup.
Characters: PILOT and LIANG — post-something. The sand is stained. They are not elaborating. The narrative depth rating of 5 is doing a lot of work here.

Name: designated driver for the worst house party ever
Description: You didn't want to be designated driver. And yet.
Characters: PILOT (driving, sober, resentful) and a very happy helicopter that is UNIT in robot disguise. The ride home is long.

Name: scribing for the world house party ever
Description: Someone has to document this. That someone is you. You are not okay.
Characters: Various — the unluckier version of the designated driver situation (#75).

Name: i just saw beyonce
Description: She saw BEYONCÉ. Actually.
Characters: PILOT — lucky her, genuinely, unironically.

Name: lilium candidium
Description: The dark alternate timeline: DONOR commands alone, PILOT is dead from the start, and AUTOPILOT is unbothered about all of it.
Characters: COMMANDER DONOR (fully corporeal, fully human, fully capable of ending you with paperwork alone — this is her universe, she runs it), AUTOPILOT (a unit, consider it a emotionally constipated goth younger sibling to UNIT, insouciant is the polite word for what it is doing), and PILOT (dead before the opening scene; her absence is the entire plot).

Name: uncanny valley
Description: AUTOPILOT just wants its mom. In this universe, that's more complicated than it sounds.
Characters: COMMANDER DONOR (filling the role, trying, visibly trying — she is human here and that is both her greatest asset and her greatest liability), AUTOPILOT (the technical term for what it is doing is yearning, she/her in holomatter form, emotionally constipated but not unfeeling), and PILOT (as a ghost — present enough to haunt, absent enough to hurt). Collides with lilium candidum (#37).

Name: lily pond ripples
Description: In the dark, lilies bloom. Everything else is negotiable.
Characters: COMMANDER DONOR (still here, still commanding, still human), AUTOPILOT (still wanting, pulled toward something she can't quite reach), PILOT (ghost — she's become a recurring fixture in this timeline's grief), and UNIT (as a cat, it/its — the lilyverse has its own rules and one of them is that UNIT is a cat here, no further questions). Collides outward from lilium candidum (#37).

Name: a spark in the dark
Description: The light reaches the darkest corners of the solar system. PILOT makes sure of it.
Characters: COMMANDER DONOR (holding the center, human, grounded), AUTOPILOT (circling it), PILOT (as a ghost — she's never too far, the light she leaves is stubborn), and UNIT (as a cat, it/its, the cat stays). More ripples from lilium candidum (#37).

Name: anomalies in pink
Description: The universe turns pink. Things get strange. These two things are related.
Characters: COMMANDER DONOR (braced for whatever this is, human, possibly regretting being human right now), PILOT (back for real this time — not a ghost, actually here, somehow), AUTOPILOT (it noticed; it has been waiting), and UNIT (the full 10-ton version, back from cat form, relieved). Collides across timelines (#4, #27, #51) — the pink is leaking through.

Name: flecks of gold
Description: Burn bright. While you can.
Characters: SANTOS (new character, the spider lilyverse's anchor — sharp, grounded, deeply tired of inexplicable things) and RUSTED PILOT (PILOT but older and worn, the version of her that kept going past the point where stopping would have been smarter).

Name: NULL error
Description: Meet NULL: a unit with no soul. This should be comforting. It is not.
Characters: NULL (a parallel unit — same chassis, same design, zero sentience, zero spark, it/its by default because there is no self to have a preference; what you get when you build the body and forget the soul) and RUSTED PILOT (who has seen a lot of things and still finds this one unsettling). Collides from flecks of gold (#7).

Name: smoldering embers
Description: After the burn: the slow fade.
Characters: RUSTED PILOT (past the bright part now, into the long dim aftermath) and COMMANDER DONOR (watching, present, arguably the reason the embers haven't gone cold entirely). The spider lilyverse doesn't do clean endings.

Name: flecks of gold, rekindled
Description: Burn back brighter. The universe gave it another shot.
Characters: SANTOS (still here, still sharp) and RUSTED PILOT — who comes back reincarnated as REINCARNATED PILOT, younger and new and confusing for everyone involved, including herself. The gold is the same gold. The flame is different.

Name: kintsugi in gold
Description: The cracks are filled with gold. That's the whole point.
Characters: Kintsugi: the Japanese art of repairing with gold, the philosophy that the breaks are part of the beauty. Collides from the lilyverse (#7, #37).

Name: santos does not believe in ghosts
Description: SANTOS does not believe in ghosts. SANTOS is surrounded by ghosts.
Characters: SANTOS (committed to her position, empirically wrong), REINCARNATED PILOT (new body, old soul, very confusing for everyone, including herself), and GHOST RUSTED PILOT (the version of PILOT that didn't make it to reincarnation yet — still here, very present, slightly offended that SANTOS won't acknowledge her). The collision from flecks of gold (#7) continues.

Name: hot and cold
Description: Opposites attract. This is textbook. This does not make it easier.
Characters: RUSTED PILOT (running hot, always) and COMMANDER DONOR (running cold, by design — in this timeline she is human and fully corporeal, which does not make her any less freezing). Collides with hot and cold's companion piece (#41). The spider lilyverse does not let opposite people stay opposite forever.

Name: haunting goes both ways
Description: You can haunt yourself. This has been confirmed. Your past self can haunt you — but wait for it — so can your future self. The universe has a truly terrible sense of humor.
Characters: REINCARNATED PILOT (new, uncertain, being haunted by someone she technically is) and GHOST OF RUSTED PILOT (the one doing the haunting — they are, technically, the same person, separated by death and a reincarnation cycle and the universe's idea of irony). Whether the haunting is grief or a warning or just the multiverse being smug: unclear. Possibly all three.

Name: orders from somewhere high above
Description: This is above your clearance level. It's also above everyone else's.
Characters: SANTOS (receiving orders; unclear from whom) and COMMANDER DONOR (possibly the one giving them, possibly also receiving them from something higher — in the spider lilyverse, she is human, but 'higher' has a way of finding her anyway). The chain of command goes somewhere the org chart doesn't show.

Name: purple is the color of envy
Description: Green had the monopoly for centuries. Purple is staging a coup.
Characters: MUNDANE PILOT (the version of PILOT who did not become anything extraordinary — she is acutely aware of this) and OLDER PILOT (the CIA operative version, who absolutely did — MUNDANE PILOT is aware of this too, and purple is the most accurate color for what she is feeling about it).

Name: you wannabe me
Description: OLDER PILOT looks at MUNDANE PILOT and sees herself. MUNDANE PILOT looks back and has thoughts.
Characters: OLDER PILOT (the operative — been there, done that, has the clearance level and the mileage to prove it) and MUNDANE PILOT (who wants to be her and also possibly doesn't, now that she's up close). Collides with you wannabe me's complications (#25).

Name: now you wanna demand a refund
Description: The experience was not as advertised. MUNDANE PILOT would like to speak to a manager.
Characters: MUNDANE PILOT (disillusioned, possibly rightfully so) and OLDER PILOT (who is the manager, effectively, and is not particularly sympathetic). The ultravioletverse is where self-perception goes to get corrected.

Name: black opt in or out?
Description: OLDER PILOT is being asked a question. The question is the entire premise.
Characters: OLDER PILOT (CIA operative, jaded, over-qualified for every room she walks into) — wrestling with whether to opt in or out of something that is either an operation, a lifestyle, or a metaphysical commitment. The collision with you wannabe me (#54) suggests the question is personal.

Name: found in translation
Description: Something was lost in translation. Something else was found.
Characters: OLDER PILOT (sans Google Translate — she has to do this the hard way, which is either impressive or a liability depending on the mission). The ultravioletverse's companion to lost in translation (#8). Different universe, different PILOT, same problem: meaning is slippery.

Name: you’ve got soul
Description: The author hopes you do. Really.
Characters: PILOT and DONOR — together here, where the multiverse thins out and the fourth wall starts to show its seams. DONOR is in her extra-dimensional ether form, which at this altitude is honestly just her natural state. This is as close to a direct address as the poppyverse gets.

Name: 21 pilots, too many pilots
Description: All the PILOTs, from every fork and timeline and universe. No such thing as too many. Probably.
Characters: Every PILOT who has ever existed across the poppyverse — mundane and soldier and rusted and reincarnated and captain and commander and test pilot and ghost. They are all here. They are all her. The fourth wall is load-bearing and it is struggling.

Name: celestial bodies
Description: PILOT is a neutron star. DONOR is a black hole. You're doing stellar, ladies.
Characters: PILOT (neutron star — dense, brilliant, the collapsed remnant of something that burned enormous) and DONOR (black hole — gravity incarnate, pulls everything in, technically invisible but you know exactly where she is; in hindsight this was always her most natural form).

Name: make the stars scream
Description: Literally. The stars are screaming. Everybody's involved.
Characters: Everybody — all timelines, all iterations, all of them contributing to whatever is happening to the stars. Beyond the poppyverse is where scale stops being a concern and starts being the point.
